title: Building a Small Network
description: Network design, device selection, scalability, and best practices for small business networks

keyConcepts.title: Network Design Considerations
keyConcepts.description: Small networks require careful balancing of cost, functionality, and future growth. Key factors include device modularity, redundancy planning, and selecting appropriate port density.

keyConcepts.title: Redundancy
keyConcepts.description: Critical for large corporations but often too expensive for small businesses. Involves duplicate routers, ISP links, and power supplies to eliminate single points of failure and ensure business continuity.

keyConcepts.title: Modularity
keyConcepts.description: Selecting devices that support expansion modules allows networks to grow without replacing core equipment. Essential for businesses with growth forecasts to protect initial investment.

keyConcepts.title: Quality of Service (QoS)
keyConcepts.description: Mechanism to prioritize delay-sensitive traffic like voice and video over data traffic. Manages bandwidth allocation and reduces latency during network congestion.

keyConcepts.title: Network Baseline
keyConcepts.description: Should be established at regular intervals over time to capture normal performance under various load conditions. Used for capacity planning and identifying performance degradation.

keyConcepts.title: Network Documentation
keyConcepts.description: Essential element of scaling networks. Includes physical and logical topology diagrams, IP addressing schemes, device inventory, and configuration backups.

importantPoints: Cost is typically the most constrained factor in small network design
Redundancy is more important to large corporations than small businesses
Modularity protects investment by allowing future expansion
Voice and video traffic require delay-sensitive delivery (QoS)
Voice traffic typically has highest priority through network
QoS minimizes latency for real-time applications
Network baseline should be established at regular intervals over time
True redundancy requires second router AND second ISP
Network documentation identifies physical and logical topologies
169.254.x.x indicates DHCP failure (APIPA)
DNS failure: can reach site by IP but not by URL
Debug output sent to console line by default
Use 'terminal monitor' to see debug on VTY lines
tracert (Windows) / traceroute (Linux) shows path to destination
show interfaces displays speed, duplex, and Layer 1/2 status
show ip interface brief shows IP addresses and up/down status
CDP can be disabled globally or per-interface
CDP operates at Layer 2, doesn't require Layer 3 connectivity
Fixed-interface devices less flexible for growing networks
Port density should match current and projected needs
